questions.text: Identify the organization that has the given emblem:

choices.text: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme
National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke

questions.solution:
The given image is the emblem of National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP).

Characteristics of NLEP emblem:

  • The lotus in the NLEP emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb, a normal forefinger, and the shape of a house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of the society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of leprosy.

NLEP is a centrally sponsored health scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Option A: National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

Option C: Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS)

Option D: National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

questions.text: The Sparsh campaign was launched to spread awareness about which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Sparsh Leprosy Awareness Campaign (SLAC) was introduced in 2017 on the occasion of the anti-leprosy day (observed on the last Sunday of January) to promote awareness about various aspects of leprosy.

Sapna refers to a local school-going girl who will help to spread awareness in the community.

The other developments under NLEP are:

  • Mycobacterium Indicus Prani (MiP) vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts (it is in a project mode).
  • Nikusth: A web-based system for the data management of leprosy cases.

Note: Meena is a nine-year-old girl, who is the symbol of UNICEF's Girl Empowerment programme to impart important messages on gender, child rights, education, health and development in the South Asian region.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy comes to the PHC following a pinprick to his foot. He noticed it only after seeing bloodstains on the floor and complains of loss of sensation in his foot. After addressing the issue, the patient is referred to another centre. Where has he been referred to and why?

choices.text: For secondary prevention to a district hospital.
For tertiary prevention to a district hospital.
For secondary prevention to a district nucleus.
For tertiary prevention to a district nucleus.

questions.solution: The given clinical scenario of a patient with leprosy having neuropathy needs Micro Cellular Rubber (MCR) footwear, which is a form of tertiary prevention. He is to be referred to a district nucleus which supplies MCR footwear to patients.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy, who has completed a course of multi-drug therapy, presents with complaints of developing painful, tender, and raised lesions on his forehead recently as shown in the image below. What is the first-line treatment for him?

choices.text: Restart multi drug therapy and start thalidomide
Restart multi drug therapy and start prednisolone

questions.solution:
The presence of new erythematous and tender subcutaneous nodules in a patient with leprosy indicates that he has developed type II lepra reaction. It is also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) and the first line of treatment is prednisolone.

Multi-drug therapy (MDT) should not be restarted in patients who develop lepra reactions after the completion of treatment.

Prednisolone is started at a dose of 40 mg per day and gradually tapered by 5 mg every 2 weeks. 'Prednisolone card' is given when treatment is started. If the patient becomes steroid-dependent, then clofazimine is added.

The  key targets of the Global Leprosy Strategy 2021-2023 announced by WHO (Accelerating towards a leprosy-free world) are:

  • 120 countries reporting zero new autochthonous cases.
  • 70% reduction in the annual number of new cases detected.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million population of new cases with Grade 2 disability.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million children of new child cases with leprosy.

The current goal is the elimination of leprosy.

questions.text: ABSULS, which is an ASHA-based surveillance project, has been initiated for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution: ABSULS which stands for Asha Based Surveillance for Leprosy Suspects has been initiated to prioritize leprosy case detection by ASHAs.

questions.text: The treatment of paucibacillary leprosy consists of MDT (which comprises rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine). The latest recommended regimen is:
questions.solution:
The latest recommendation is 3 drug therapy for 6 months to treat paucibacillary (PB) leprosy by WHO. The regimen consists of rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine.

Meanwhile, multibacillary (MB) leprosy is treated using the same 3 drugs for a duration of 12 months. While the NLEP guidelines earlier mentioned a 2-drug MDT for PB leprosy, the National Strategic Plan and Roadmap for Leprosy (2023-2027) now recommends a uniform MDT of 3 drugs for both PB and MB leprosy.

Note: The central government has approved a new treatment regimen for paucibacillary (PB) leprosy. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare has introduced a 3-drug regimen for PB leprosy instead of a 2-drug regimen. This revised drug regimen will be applicable in India from April 1, 2025.

questions.text: A District Leprosy Officer is preparing the annual report as per NLEP 2020. Which of the following parameters would he not consider as an essential indicator?

choices.text: Rate of new cases with Grade II disabilities per 10 lakh population per year
Proportion of new cases correctly diagnosed

questions.solution:
The proportion of new cases correctly diagnosed is not included under essential indicators. It is a part of the quality of service indicators as per NLEP 2020. 

The essential indicators include:

  • Annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) per 1 lakh population.
  • Rate of new cases with grade II disabilities (G2D) per 10 lakh population per year.
  • Treatment completion rate (TCR) as a proxy to cure rate.
  • Prevalence rate (PR).

Additional epidemiological indicators include:

  • Proportion of Grade II disabilities among new cases.
  • Proportion of females among new cases. 
  • Proportion of multibacillary (MB) among new cases.
  • Proportion of child (0- 14 years) among new cases. 
  • Child rate per 100,000 population. 
  • Scheduled Caste New Case Detection Rate.

questions.text: As per NLEP 2020, which of the following is not a quality of service indicator?

choices.text: Patient month blister calendar pack stock
Proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases.
Proportion of cases who developed new or additional disability after starting  MDT

questions.solution:
Proportion of grade II disabilities among new cases is not a quality of service indicator. It is an additional epidemiological indicator as per NLEP 2020.

The quality of service indicators are: 

  • Patient month blister calendar pack stock. 
  • Absolute number of patients made released from treatment (RFT).     
  • Number of relapse reported. 
  • Proportion of cases who developed new or additional disability after starting MDT. 
  • Proportion of treatment defaulters.
  • Proportion of new cases correctly diagnosed.

questions.text: You are part of a rural health camp organized under Project Axshya. Which of the following diseases does it aim to control?
questions.solution:
Project Axshya was launched in 2010 to control TB. Axshya means free from TB which is the ultimate goal of the project and the National TB Elimination Programme.

Project Axshya is being implemented by the International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease (known simply as The Union). The project works to improve access to quality TB care and control through a partnership between the government and civil society.

The guiding principles of project Axshya are:

  • Universal access to quality TB services
  • Community participation in TB care and control
  • Sustainable interventions and equitable distribution of project benefits with social and gender sensitivity

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a PHC where you diagnose a patient with TB. Within how many days do you have to report it to the District Health Officer?
questions.solution:
The guidelines for TB notification under the RNTCP is within 30 days (a month) of receiving a new case. The notification must be done to the District Health Officer or the Chief Medical Officer of a District Hospital by the practitioner who diagnosed it.

Note: RNTCP has now been renamed to National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme?

choices.text: Follow-up sputum smear examination at the end of intensive phase only
Directly Observed Treatment Short course strategy is applied
Treatment is only given to smear positive cases
MDR TB is resistance to either rifampicin or isoniazid

questions.solution:
DOTS stands for Directly Observed Treatment Short-course and is given by peripheral and voluntary health workers.

Recent updates in RNTCP:

  • Active case finding for TB has been started.
  • Follow up: 
    • On treatment: monthly follow up. 
    • After treatment: Follow up at 6, 12, 18 and 24 months.
    • A sputum smear examination must be done at the end of intensive phase (IP) and at the end of treatment.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Related Pearl: Classification of TB Patients Based on History of Treatment

New case is defined as a TB patient who had

  • Never taken ATT previously or
  • Taken ATT for < 1 month

Previously treated Case : Patients who have received 1 month or more of Anti TB drugs in the past. These include:

  1. Recurrent TB: A TB patient who had completed course of treatment / declared cured and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case
  2. Treatment after failure: Patients who had been treated for TB and their treatment failed at the end of most recent course of treatment
  3. Treatment after loss to follow up: A TB patient who had been treated > 1 month on ATT and registered as lost to follow up and now presenting as microbiologically confirmed case of TB
  4. Other previously treated patients: Patients who had been previously treated but whose outcome is now unknown/undocumented

Transferred in: A TB patient who has been received in a TB unit after having registered in another TB unit for treatment.

choices.text: Resistance to INH + Amikacin + Ofloxacin + Ethambutol
Resistance to INH + Rifampicin + Ofloxacin + Linezolid

questions.text: A patient on HAART presents with complaints of fever and expectorant cough for two weeks. What is the investigation to be ordered first?
questions.solution:
An HIV patient suspected to have TB is directly investigated by CB-NAAT (Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test).

TB is a very serious infection in the immunocompromised and can lead to its most severe form as miliary TB and cause death. Since TB in HIV does not have its typical presentation, early suspicion and advanced diagnosis is the key to preventing mortality.

Diagnostic algorithm for TB:

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

questions.text: Which of the following is the most peripheral centre under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme organization structure?
questions.solution: Among the options given, Designated Microscopy Centre is the most peripheral centre.

questions.text: Which is the new online software launched under the national tuberculosis elimination program (NTEP) by the government to monitor TB patients?
questions.solution:
Nikshay is the new online software launched under the national tuberculosis elimination program for monitoring TB patients.

Nikusth is the new online software for monitoring leprosy patients.

Nischay is a pregnancy test kit.

questions.text: Choose the false statement regarding the initiatives and strategies for tuberculosis.

choices.text: The Stop TB strategy was announced by the World Health Organisation
The STOP TB strategy has a target of ending TB by achieving an  incidence rate of <10 people per 10,000 population per year
The "Practical approach to lung health" was launched by the WHO for syndromic managment of patients with respiratory symptoms
The End TB strategy is a 20 year programme

questions.solution:
The Stop TB strategy was announced by World Health Organisation to reduce the global burden of TB by 2015 (and not ending TB). 

The End TB strategy is a 20-year programme with tagline “A world free of TB - Zero TB deaths, Zero TB disease, and Zero TB suffering”. It aims to:

  • end TB by achieving an incidence rate of <10 people/1 lakh population per year by 2035. 
  • reduce TB deaths by 95% and cut new cases by 90% by 2035.

 The "Practical approach to lung health initiative" was launched by the WHO as a syndromic approach to the management of patients who attend primary health care services for respiratory symptoms.

Ending the TB epidemic is also one of the targets of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG) specifically under Goal 3 (to “ensure healthy lives and promote well-being for all at all ages”).

Vision of End TB: A world free of TB- zero deaths, disease and suffering due to TB
Goal: End the global TB epidemic
Indicators Targets
  SDG 2030 End TB 2035
Reduction in no. of TB deaths compared with 2015 90% 95%
Reduction in TB incidence rate compared with 2015

80%

(<20/1,00,000)

90%

(<10/1,00,000)
TB-affected families facing catastrophic costs due to TB 0% 0%

WHO defines that "Tuberculosis control" would be achieved when the prevalence of the natural order of infection in the age group of 0-14 years is of the order of 1% (40% in India currently).

World TB Day is observed annually on March 24 to raise awareness about TB and efforts to end the global epidemic, marking the day in 1882 when the bacterium causing TB was discovered. This year's theme is 'Yes! We can end TB!', aims to inspire hope and encourage faster uptake of new WHO recommendations, adoption of innovations, accelerated action, and multisectoral collaboration to combat the TB epidemic

questions.text: Which of the following group of individuals would you not target under the programme represented by the logo shown below?
questions.solution:
The red ribbon shown is a part of the logo of the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) programme. Industrial workers are not included in the target population under NACO.

Target interventions for the control of AIDS transmission are done for:

  • High-risk groups like sex workers
  • Men who have sex with men
  • Transgender
  • Injecting drug users
  • Bridge population like migrants and long-distance truckers

The services offered through targeted interventions include detection and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases and condom distribution.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the target interventions under National AIDS Control Organisation?

choices.text: Lubricants are given to  homosexual men
Clean needles and syringes are given to injecting drug users
Condoms are not given to bridge population
Opioid substitution therapy is given to Injecting Drug Users

questions.solution:
Bridge populations are supplied with condoms under the NACO target interventions. 

Target interventions: 

General:

  • Detection and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases
  • Condom distribution

For injecting drug users:

  • Distribution of clean needles and syringes.
  • Abscess prevention and management.
  • Opioid substitution therapy.
  • Linkage with detoxification and rehabilitation services.

For homosexual men and transgenders:

  • Provision of lubricants.
  • Provision of project-based clinics for sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A physician follows the two test protocol for the diagnosis of HIV in a patient. It consists of:

choices.text: Western blot as the first test
Line immunoassay as the second test
HIV ELISA as the second test
Western blot  as the second test

questions.solution:
The two test protocol for the diagnosis of HIV consists of ELISA as the second test. If the initial ELISA is positive, a second ELISA is carried out. If the second ELISA is also positive, only then the case is reported to be positive.

Investigations involved in HIV testing strategies:

  1. ELISA/ rapid tests.
  2. Confirmatory tests with high specificity like western blot and line immunoassays are used in problem cases eg: indeterminate/ discordant cases of rapid tests.

In India, NACO provides western blot (WB) confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing. It is not used for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests. Drawbacks of WB include low rates of detection during acute HIV infection and misclassification of HIV-2 infection.

Note: The western blot is used as a confirmatory test after 2 indeterminate primary tests (ELISA). It is essentially the third test used and does not fit into the two test protocol.

questions.text: As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under the National AIDS Control Programme, your duties include all of the following except:

choices.text: Estimation of total infection in the community
Estimation of total cases in hospitals

questions.solution:
As a medical officer involved in the sentinel surveillance, the estimation of total cases in hospitals is not included in the sentinel surveillance for HIV under National AIDS Control Programme (NACO).

The aims of the HIV sentinel surveillance include:

  • Determine the level of HIV infection in the community.
  • Understand the trends of HIV epidemic.
  • Understand the geographical spread of HIV infection and classify districts according to epidemiological and vulnerability criteria.

These objectives are achieved by conducting annual cross-sectional surveys of the risk group in the same geographical place.
